metadata.title: Isolation and contact tracing can tip the scale 1 to containment of COVID-19 in populations with social 2 distancing 3 4

abstract.text: 15 16 Background: Novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) has extended its range of transmission in all 17 parts of the world, with substantial variation in rates of transmission and severity of 18 associated disease. Many countries have implemented social distancing as a measure to 19 control further spread.

body_text.text: As of early April 2020, the number of infections of the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2) is still 68 increasing at an exponential rate in many countries, while the virus is expanding its range to 69 all parts of the world. There are no registered effective medicines, treatment options are 70 mainly supportive, and there are no vaccines available, limiting preventive measures mainly 71 to social distancing combined with isolation of infected persons and those that have high 72 likelihood of being infected, for instance because they have been traced as contacts of 73 infected persons [1, 2] . However, recently it was questioned by high-ranked officials of the 74 World Health Organization (WHO) whether social distancing or lockdowns are sufficient to 75 stop the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus- 76 who-ryan/lockdowns-not-enough-to-defeat-coronavirus-whos-ryan-idUSKBN2190FM). To what extent local containment or local slowing down of an epidemic by isolation and 84 contact tracing is successful depends on the fraction of infections that remain asymptomatic 85 or have mild disease, and on the infectiousness before the onset of symptoms [4, 5] . It is 86 known that a high probability of asymptomatic infection, a high proportion of transmission 87 occurring before the onset of symptoms, a long delay between case finding and isolation, 88 and high overall transmissibility all factor in negatively in the likelihood that an outbreak can 89 6 be contained [6] [7] [8] [9] . For SARS-CoV-2, evidence indicates that a high fraction of infected 90 persons is infectious before they show symptoms (up to 50%), that a substantial fraction of 91 infections may be asymptomatic or show only mild symptoms (up to 80%), and that the We focus on conditions that make containment of an early epidemic possible, but also on 106 the impact of isolation and contact tracing when containment is not possible, or in an exit 107 phase from social distancing. In a population with social distancing in place, we investigate 108 what the additional impact of isolation and contact tracing can be for reaching containment 109 or slowing down the spread. We report effective reproduction number, the (exponential) 110 rate of increase, and the doubling time of the epidemic for scenarios with various 111 combinations of interventions. Considering that the capacity of healthcare systems is 112 . (which was not peer-reviewed) The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint limited, it is important to assess which interventions are most effective in slowing down the 113 rate of increase of healthcare demand during an ongoing outbreak. As it is likely that, on the 114 one hand, isolation and contact tracing will be more effective in close contact settings with 115 well-defined contacts (household, workplace) than in the community (commuting, public CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. Table 1) . We distinguish 131 between household contacts and non-household contacts, which differ in the risk of 132 infection and the delay and effectiveness of tracing and isolation. Intervention effectiveness 133 is determined by the daily probability of being diagnosed during the infectious period (Table   134 2). Furthermore, intervention effectiveness depends on the delays in tracing household and 135 non-household contacts, respectively, and the proportions of contacts can be found and 136 isolated. We assume that isolation is perfect, i.e. that isolated persons cannot transmit any Natural history 142 We assume that the latent period lasts between 4 and 6 days. Individuals then become 143 infectious for at most 10 days. Infectivity is high at the beginning of the infectious period 144 and decays to low levels during these 10 days ( Figure S1a ). The probability of symptoms 145 onset increases during the first 4 days of the infectious period, thereby influencing the daily 146 probability of diagnosis during the infectious period (see below). 147 An infectious individual makes contacts with household members and persons outside the 148 household. We model the daily number of household contacts with a Poisson distribution, 149 and the numbers of non-household contacts with a negative binomial distribution (Table 1) , 150 with parameters based on the average household size in the Netherlands, and numbers of 151 contacts observed in a contact study in the Netherlands (FigureS1b) [20] . With the chosen 152 parameters, the mean number of contacts per day is 13.2 (SD 8.5). 153 On each day of the infectious period, an individual makes a number of contacts according to 154 the contact distribution. This number is reduced by a factor describing the probability that 155 the contact person has already been infected during earlier contacts with the index person. 156 More precisely, the number of contacts is reduced by a factor fk per day k of the infectious 157 period, describing the probability that a contact has already been infected on previous days 158 of the infectious period of the index case. The probability of transmission upon contact with 159 a susceptible household contact is given by the distribution in Figure S1a . As contacts with 160 persons outside the household are often less close, we assume that the transmission 161 probability for these contacts is lower by factor 0.25. Figure CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint reduced. This is implemented by a reduction factor in the mean of the negative binomial 171 distribution describing non-household contact numbers. The reduction factor for social 172 distancing was varied between 0% and 95%. In scenarios with social distancing we assumed 173 that only 60% of cases are symptomatic or can be ascertained. If an individual is diagnosed, contacts will be traced, and in case they are infected will be 191 diagnosed and isolated. Tracing goes back in time to trace all contacts during the infectious 192 period of the index case. There may be a delay before contacts are found and diagnosed, 193 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint and only a fraction of all contacts may be found. These parameters, tracing delay and tracing 194 coverage, may be different for household and non-household contacts. We assume that all 195 traced infected persons are immediately isolated and cannot transmit any further. 196 Therefore, the only individuals who will continue transmitting are those who are not found 197 by tracing and are not yet diagnosed. 198 199 Baseline scenario 200 For assessing the effectiveness of contact tracing and isolation, we use a best case scenario, 201 where all parameters are set to optimistic values. We assume that when a case is diagnosed, 202 he/she will immediately be isolated and this will stop onward transmission completely. 203 Furthermore, we assume that all contacts will be traced, and if found infected will be 204 isolated immediately. We assume that it takes 1 day to find and isolate both household and 205 non-household contacts. The rationale for using these overly optimistic assumptions as a 206 baseline is that we want to investigate the maximum contribution contact tracing can 207 provide for achieving containment. In sensitivity analyses we investigated for various control 208 parameters at which point of diverging from the baseline parameters control of the 209 outbreak will be lost (Supplementary Information).

Output variables 212 We compute cumulative numbers of cases for a time period of 50 days after the epidemic 213 has reached more than 100 cases. We compare doubling time of the epidemic with only 214 isolation of diagnosed cases to situations with various levels of social distancing, isolation 215 and contact tracing. We assume that all diagnosed cases are isolated upon diagnosis and 216 . The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint cannot transmit further. We plot the epidemic from the time the cumulative number of 217 infected persons is above 100. We compare these trajectories to similar trajectories for 218 China, Germany, Italy, Japan, Turkey, and the US using data downloaded from 219 ourworldindata.org [19] . We show what the additional contribution of isolation and contact 220 tracing can be in the attempt to bend the curve towards longer doubling times. We then CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. If then also 20% of non-household contacts can be traced and isolated, the 329 transition to containment can be made. to bring the balance towards containment. If social distancing is less severe, more intensive 350 contact tracing and also tracing of non-household contacts is needed (Figures 3 and 4) . If 351 . The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint social distancing reduces non-household contacts only by 50%, tracing and isolation also of 352 non-household contacts is needed for containment. If this is not possible, for example due 353 to constraints of the public health system, tracing and isolation of household contacts can at 354 least substantially increase the doubling time of the epidemic (Figure 3b ). is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. A limitation of the analyses presented here is that they apply to a situation in which the 394 epidemic is described by a branching process and is growing exponentially. This also applies 395 to another modelling using a (one-type) branching process.

[27] Ultimately, as the number of 396 persons who are or have been infected increases, the number of persons that are still 397 . CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.03.10.20033738 doi: medRxiv preprint susceptible will start to dwindle, and epidemic growth will ultimately come to a halt. Hence, 398 strictly speaking our results apply to the early stages of an epidemic. In fact, even when the 399 number of infected persons is still relatively small in the early stage of an epidemic it is 400 possible that exponential growth is not observed, for instance due to local depletion of is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

FIGREF0.text: levels of social distancing. We use a stochastic transmission model in which every person 23 generates novel infections according to a probability distribution that is affected by the 24 incubation period distribution (time from infection to symptoms), distribution of the latent 25 period (time from infection to onset of infectiousness), and overall transmissibility. The 26 model distinguishes between close contacts (e.g., within a household) and other contacts in 27 the population. Social distancing affects the number of contacts outside but not within The proportion of asymptomatic or unascertained cases has a strong impact on the 30 controllability of the disease. If the proportion of asymptomatic infections is larger than 31 30%, contact tracing and isolation cannot achieve containment for an R0 of 2.5. Achieving 32 containment by social distancing requires a reduction of numbers of non-household 33 contacts by around 90%. Depending on the realized level of contact reduction, tracing and 34 isolation of only household contacts, or of household and non-household contacts are 35 necessary to reduce the effective reproduction number to below 1. A combination of has caused over 850,000 confirmed cases of COVID-19. In the absence of 49 effective medicines and vaccines, the preventive measures are limited to social distancing, 50 isolation of confirmed and suspected cases and identification of their contacts. Using a 51 transmission model, we evaluated the impact of social distancing, isolation and contact 52 tracing on slowing down or even containing COVID-19 epidemics. We investigated how 53 various combinations of social distancing, isolation, and contact tracing reduce the effective 54 reproduction number, and what is needed to achieve the critical threshold of a reproduction 55 number below 1. We estimated the impact of combinations of measures on epidemic 56 growth rate and doubling time for the number of infections. We find that under realistic 57 assumptions on the level of social distancing, additional isolation and contact tracing are 58 needed for stopping the epidemic. Whether quarantining only household contacts is 59 sufficient, depends on levels of social distancing and timeliness of tracing and isolation. Our 60 analyses, based on best understanding of the epidemiology of COVID-19, highlight that even 61 if social distancing is in place, isolation and contact tracing at least of household contacts are 62 needed to stop the epidemic, and these additional measures help to delay and lower the 63 epidemic peak. Therefore, isolation and contact tracing will be important tools for enabling 64 exiting of currently implemented social distancing measures. Introduction 67

FIGREF1.text: measures are needed, for example active tracing of contacts in 78 combination with isolation of infected contacts. Also, such measures will be important in the 79 context of exit strategies, i.e. once social distancing measures are reduced or lifted, as has 80 been suggested recently [3]. It is unclear, how effective such combinations of interventions 81 can be in populations with social distancing in place. 82 83

FIGREF2.text: 92 epidemic doubling time in the absence of interventions is approximately one week or 93 perhaps even less [5, 10-16]. On the other hand, it is also reported that with intensive 94 contact tracing it may be possible to trace the majority (>80%) of secondary infections [17]. 95 96 Here we provide model-based analyses of the impact of isolation and contact tracing in a 97 setting with various levels of social distancing measures, using varying levels of the 98 effectiveness and timeliness of contact tracing. It is important to consider the impact of each 99 of these interventions in isolation but also in combination, as it is well known that each 100 intervention that reduces transmission in the population (i.e. reduces the reproduction 101 number) is expected to increase the effectiveness of additional interventions in a synergistic 102 manner [18]. We show how those measures impact on the cumulative numbers of infecteds 103 during an outbreak and compare with recent outbreak data from various countries [19]. 104 105

FIGREF3.text: 116 spaces), while, on the other hand, the potential impact of household interventions on the 117 epidemic could be smaller, we stratify the analyses by transmission setting (henceforth 118 called household and non-household) [8]. As many of the relevant epidemiological and 119 intervention parameters are still quite uncertain, or may be variable in different settings, we 120 focus throughout on a systematic analysis of the relation between key parameters for 121 timeliness and completeness of contact tracing and main outcomes such as the effective 122 reproduction number and the epidemic growth rate. 123 124 .

FIGREF4.text: describes an epidemic in its early phase as a branching process. Starting 127 from a small set of initially infected individuals, the model calculates the numbers of latently 128 infected persons, infectious persons, and persons that are diagnosed and isolated in time 129 steps of one day. Latent infection, infectivity during the infectious period, and daily contact 130 rates are quantified using distributions taken from the literature (

FIGREF5.text: 137 longer. The model is described by a set of difference equations, and allows for explicit 138 computation of the basic reproduction number R0 and the effective reproduction number 139 under interventions Re. The model was coded in Mathematica 12.

FIGREF6.text: S1c shows the percentage of162    onward transmissions per day of the infectious period, e.g. more than half of all onward 163 transmissions occur during the first 3 days of the infectious period. can be self-imposed, if people decide to reduce their social contacts during 167 the outbreak, and it can be government-imposed by closing schools, workplaces, and other 168 venues of social gatherings. Here we assume that when social distancing is applied,169    household contacts remain unchanged, but the mean number of non-household contacts is 170 .

FIGREF7.text: person becomes symptomatic with a given probability per day of the infectious 177 period. For SARS-CoV-2 the probability of developing symptoms is high in the first few days 178 of the infectious period. We assume that if an infected and infectious person has not 179 developed symptoms by day 6, the probability that he/she will still do so is very small. The 180 probability of developing symptoms determines whether he/she will be diagnosed and 181 isolated. The total probability of developing symptoms determines the fraction that remains 182 asymptomatic or otherwise undiagnosed, i.e. if the total probability of developing symptoms 183 is smaller than 1, a proportion of the infected persons will remain undiagnosed and can 184 transmit throughout their infectious period. With the assumed distributions, on average 185 about half of all potential onward transmissions will have occurred before an infected 186 person is diagnosed and isolated. The diagnosis can be delayed, which in the model is 187 implemented by setting the diagnosis probability to zero for the number of days of delay. 188 This delay describes the time between symptom onset until a symptomatic person visits a 189 GP or hospital and gets diagnosed.

FIGREF9.text: an explicit calculation of the basic reproduction number R0 and the 222 effective reproduction number Re [8]. R0 is defined as the number of secondary cases an 223 index case generates on average in a susceptible population, and Re is the number of 224 secondary infections per case when an intervention is in place. R0 is determined by daily 225 transmission probabilities and numbers of contacts. The effective reproduction number is in 226 addition determined by the level of social distancing, diagnosis probabilities, tracing delays, 227 and tracing coverages per day of the infectious period. We can therefore investigate how Re 228 depends on R0 and on the intervention parameters. 229 We are interested in the critical tracing coverage, i.e. what proportion of non-household 230 contacts needs to be found and isolated to control the outbreak, for populations with 231 various levels of social distancing. Furthermore, we study the epidemic growth rate (or 232 epidemic doubling time) without and with contact tracing and isolation and various levels of 233 social distancing. In sensitivity analyses, we study how these quantities depend on the delay 234 to diagnosis of cases and on the delay in contact tracing. For example, we assume that 235 household contacts can be traced with a high coverage and without delay, but that tracing 236 of non-household contact may take longer and be less complete. 237 Based on the distribution of the latent and infectious periods and infectivity, we calculate 238 the exponential growth rate and doubling time under various assumptions on the 239 intervention parameters. This gives additional information for situations where the outbreak 240 .

FIGREF10.text: growth rate, and doubling time of the epidemic. We varied levels of social246    distancing, and coverage of tracing of household and non-household contacts. In our247    analysis for different levels of social distancing we assumed that 60% of infected of the study had no role in study design, data collection, data analysis, data 252 interpretation, writing of the manuscript, or the decision to submit for publication. All 253 authors had full access to all the data in the study and were responsible for the decision baseline scenario without interventions we calibrate the transmission probability such 260 that the basic reproduction number equals R0 = 2.5. In that case, 39% of transmissions prevented, the outbreak would be just under the control limit. In the baseline 264 scenario without interventions the exponential growth rate is 0.19 per day and the doubling265 time is 3.6 days, which agrees with published estimates [13]. For sensitivity analysis of the 266 relation between R0 and Re for various combinations of parameters, diagnosed cases alone reduces the doubling time to almost 4 days. If social 270 distancing is implemented 28 days after the first case was diagnosed, and the number of 271 non-household contacts is reduced by 70% [21], the doubling time will increase to around 14 272 days (Figure 1a). The figure also shows that it takes a week before the impact on the 273 epidemic growth starts to be visible. If higher levels of social distancing can be achieved, the 274 doubling times can be increased more (Figure 1b), but even for 90% reduction of contacts 275 the curve has not been flattened. In Figure 1c the impact of the timing of social distancing 276 measures on the further course of the outbreak is shown. The figure demonstrates how 277 every week delay in implementing these measures leads to an order of magnitude higher 278 numbers of cases, thus emphasizing the importance of fast implementation of social 279 distancing measures. Finally, in Figure 4d we show a scenario where social distancing is 280 implemented at day 28 after diagnosing the first case and reduces non-household contacts 281 by 70%. Then at day 49, also contact tracing is implemented. It is assumed that all infected 282 household contacts and 50% of the non-household contacts of a newly diagnosed case are 283 traced and isolated. This additional measure increases the doubling time to … days. We 284 .

FIGREF11.text: non-household contacts needed to trace and isolate288    If there is a diagnosis delay, the question arises how successful contact tracing has to be to289    keep the outbreak under control. We therefore compute the minimum fraction of non-290 household contacts that need to be traced and isolated (henceforth termed "critical tracing 291 coverage") to bring Re to below 1 (for examples with various assumptions on timeliness diagnosed can be a consequence of not developing symptoms, having only mild296    symptoms, or any other reason why infected persons might not be identified by health care.297    We subsume these possible reasons for cases not being ascertained under the term 298 "asymptomatic". With increasing proportion of asymptomatic cases, the possibility of 299 controlling the outbreak with contact tracing and isolation quickly fades. This is shown in where we plotted the critical tracing coverage for non-household contacts for 301 several values of R0 as a function of the fraction of symptomatic cases (i.e. the fraction of 302 those who will eventually develop symptoms during their entire infectious period).303    Household contacts are assumed to be always traced and isolated. The figure shows that for 304 R0 = 2.5 control is not possible with isolation and contact tracing, if less than 60% of all 305 infected persons develop symptoms or are otherwise not detected by the health care 306 .

FIGREF12.text: in theory can reduce the effective reproduction number to below 1, but312    only if non-household contacts are almost reduced to zero. In reality this is not possible,313    because there are many non-household contacts which cannot be avoided to keep essential 314 processes in society going. Therefore social distancing will not be complete and may not be315 sufficient for containment. Additional tracing and isolation of household contacts may then 316 be the additional effort needed to achieve containment. In figure 3a we show for various 317 levels of social distancing, expressed as proportion reduction of non-household contacts, 318 what fraction of household-or additionally non-household contacts need to be traced and 319 isolated to reduce the effective reproduction number. Similarly, figure 3b shows the 320 increase of the doubling time that can be achieved with these contact tracing measures 321 depending on level of social distancing. Figure 4a shows for various values of R0, what are 322 the critical tracing coverages of household contacts only in order to reach an effective 323 reproduction number of 1, which is the threshold to containment. If tracing household 324 contacts is not sufficient, also non-household contacts have to be traced and isolated, for 325 which the critical coverages are shown in figure 4b. For example, if social distancing leads to 326 a reduction of 50% of non-household contacts, additional tracing and isolating household 327 contacts can further reduce the effective reproduction number, but cannot

FIGREF13.text: show that rapid diagnosis and isolation of infections based on COVID-19 333 disease alone cannot control outbreaks of SARS-CoV-2, but that the addition of tracing and 334 isolation of traced cases could in theory be successful depending on the value of R0Figure 2). In practice, however, the potential for containment will be seriously jeopardized 336 by various delays and imperfections in the tracing process. Especially delays in diagnosis and 337 isolation, and the existence of asymptomatic and mild infections that contribute to onward 338 transmission will make an outbreak uncontrollable. As evidence is mounting that the 339 proportion of asymptomatic and mild cases is large and leads to substantial numbers of340 unascertained cases [22], most countries have now switched to strategies of social 341 distancing or complete lockdowns. Such measures have proven effective earlier during the 342 2009 influenza pandemic [23, 24]. However, social distancing can never be complete, as 343 healthcare workers and doctors have to continue their work, but also personnel of 344 supermarkets, public transport employees, and others need to have contact outside their 345 households. Therefore, transmission chains may remain. We find that in a situation where 346 60% of cases are ascertained, social distancing of non-household contacts fails to contain 347 the epidemic even if contacts outside the household are reduced by 80%. In that case, 348 combining the social distancing with tracing and isolation of household contacts may suffice 349

FIGREF14.text: recent report by Ferguson and colleagues (https://www.imperial.ac.uk/mrc-global-357 infectious-disease-analysis/news--wuhan-coronavirus/) it is assumed that non-household 358 contacts would be reduced by 75% by social distancing [25], and a contact study in the UK 359 shows that numbers of contacts are reduced by around 73% [21]. Using these estimates, our 360 model predicts that additional tracing and isolation of infected household contacts would 361 suffice as an additional measure to achieve containment. Possibly, this could be achieved by 362 using digital tracing applications as implemented in South Korea, where it has apparently 363 helped to bring the epidemic under control [the pandemic situation shows that COVID-19 epidemics cannot be contained by 366 contact tracing and rapid isolation alone, this does not render contact tracing useless. On 367 the contrary, contact tracing and isolation when used in addition to social distancing, may be 368 the tool needed to make this mix of strategies successful. Our analyses show that isolation 369 and contact tracing when combined with social distancing can contribute to reducing the 370 growth rate and increasing the doubling time of epidemics, thereby buying time, spreading 371 the number of severe cases out over a longer period of time, and potentially also reducing 372 the total number of infections (the "final size") [26]. This will lower peak healthcare demand, 373 alleviate the stress on healthcare systems, and contribute to reducing the burden of disease.

FIGREF15.text: , diagnosis delays), and by incorporating household versus non-household 378 contacts [27]. Household contacts are at a higher risk of becoming infected than non-379 household contacts as persons in a household will usually have repeated contacts. On the 380 other hand, our analyses show that household infections contribute less to onward 381 transmission than non-household infections simply because the numbers of household 382 contacts are much lower than numbers of other contacts. As a consequence, the 383 effectiveness in isolating non-household contacts is key for a successful of the model is that quantitative information about distributions of the latent and 387 infectious periods, and the infectivity per day of the infectious period can be incorporated 388 easily and detailed, such that if new and better data on those quantities emerge, the 389 analysis can be updated quickly. In particular, the model can incorporate non-standard 390 distributions based on empirical data (e.g. viral load measurements to quantify 391 infectiousness per day), should they become available. 392 393

FIGREF16.text: 401 susceptible persons in combination with clustering in contact patterns, spatial effects, and 402 inhomogeneous mixing [28]. However, estimates of the effective reproduction number are 403 independent of the dynamics and give information about the ability of an intervention to 404 stop of slow down epidemic spread. Also, at present the epidemics in many , our results show that in populations where social distancing is implemented, 408 isolation and contact tracing can play an essential role in gaining control of the COVID-19 409 epidemic. On their own, none of these strategies are able to contain COVID-19 for realistic 410 parameter settings, but in a combined strategy they can just tip the balance towards 411 containment. These insights provide guidance for policy makers, who will have to decide 412 when and how to release severe lockdown or social distancing measures, and whether 413 additional contact tracing and isolation is then a feasible alternative keep MvB, and GR conceived the study. MK designed and programmed the model, and 418 produced output. All authors interpreted the results, contributed to writing the manuscript, 419 and approved the final version for submission.
